text: Family Member: Oh. Exactly. Doctor: That something’s breaking through as in the shot itself is not enough. Family Member: Right. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him? Doctor: Sure. I’m a too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I’m an ah aggressive guy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Um you’re a young guy. You don’t want to look back. Or if it was me, Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I would say I wouldn’t want to look back and not do everything I could have done. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: We might not cure you, but I think psychologically, you know I’ve done everything I can. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: But that you know, people feel differently. text: Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help. Patient: Right. I got it. Doctor: What they are allowed to do there is use the material as long as they don’t try to sell it outside their hospital or use it outside the hospital, they’re allowed to do it. And the material they’re using is kind of an off-the-shelf thing where they could buy it, make it on site. Uh in the U.S. what’s gotten problematic is I think we’re on the third company now that’s tried to develop this. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The first two companies kind of went under. It’s a little bit complicated with the drug involved because it’s radioactive. You’ve got to have a whole infrastructure. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: To make sure the radiation is here on Tuesday when you’re here. It’s not like you just go over to the pharmacy and grab it because there’s all that stuff.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, the possibility of side effects is a little bit higher. Okay? And usually, those side effects are high blood pressure, leg swelling, low potassium. So, you’re going to have to monitor and stay with the visits because at least for the first few months, we’ll have to monitor you somewhat closer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Once both of us sort of get comfortable, like we did, but you got too comfortable, Doctor: With this medication Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Then, I will be able to space it further and further apart. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the first two or three months are going to be somewhat critical. Patient: The same what we did with the Casodex? Doctor: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh) Doctor: So I still think they are because, but what this says is that there is increasing uptake. So since I’m gonna give you these… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: …I wanted you to know. Unfortunately the size are the how bright it is. So increasing uptake means it’s brighter now than it was before. Patient: This is in the bones? Doctor: Correct, yeah. That grade of brightness I guess, doesn’t mean a whole lot for prostate cancer on the bone scan. Okay because even healing bone can look brighter than the other. So on the bone scan really what would tell me that there is progression of the disease would be if there were new areas and there were not. Okay? But I just needed to explain this because- Family Member: Yes. Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip?

text: Patient: Hmm. Doctor: That trial is going to take the immune system idea to the max which is okay if, more importantly, the reason is, not to oversell, but one of the things with prostate cancer that we see is, when you look at other cancers under the microscope, you see the immune system trying at least. You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there. Patient: I see. Doctor: So how, so a lot of the research is how do we get those cells attractive- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to go in the cancer? And the most extreme way would be give you a new immune system. Give you somebody else’s immune system where those cancers were foreign. Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh so right now you’re eligible for that. Maybe put that on the back burner. The one thing that would make you ineligible is going on chemotherapy.

You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there. Patient: I see. Doctor: So how, so a lot of the research is how do we get those cells attractive- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to go in the cancer? And the most extreme way would be give you a new immune system. Give you somebody else’s immune system where those cancers were foreign. Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh so right now you’re eligible for that. Maybe put that on the back burner. The one thing that would make you ineligible is going on chemotherapy.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
